facts.fact: In mainland China, domestic internet platforms and search engines commonly censor queries and posts related to the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
In mainland China, discussion of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown is politically sensitive and heavily censored by state authorities.
People in mainland China who publicly commemorate or discuss the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown may face official surveillance.
In mainland China, authorities have detained or arrested individuals for attempting to publicly commemorate the June 4 anniversary.
In the Chinese government’s official narrative, the 1989 Tiananmen protests are characterized as a “counter-revolutionary riot.”
The Chinese government promotes an official narrative portraying the 1989 protests as political turmoil that threatened social stability.
Mainland Chinese school curricula and textbooks typically omit the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests and crackdown.
In mainland China, academic discussion of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown is limited and can be subject to political restrictions and scrutiny.
Some mainland Chinese internet users attempt to discuss the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown using euphemisms, coded language, or indirect references to evade automated censorship.
Mainland China operates a nationwide internet censorship system commonly referred to as the "Great Firewall."
Around the anniversary of June 4, Chinese authorities typically increase security measures in and around Tiananmen Square.
Official Chinese accounts generally minimize or omit discussion of the scale of violence and casualties from the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Some people use coded phrases (for example, "May 35") to refer to June 4, 1989, to evade online censorship in mainland China.
In mainland China, the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown is commonly referred to with euphemisms such as the "June 4th incident" ("6/4").
In mainland China, foreign journalists attempting to report on the June 4 anniversary can face heightened monitoring, interference, or access restrictions.
Chinese government “patriotic education” messaging emphasizes national stability and the Communist Party’s role in maintaining social order.
As a result of censorship and omission from education, many younger people in mainland China have limited awareness of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Despite censorship in mainland China, some people use circumvention tools (such as VPNs) to access information about the Tiananmen crackdown from outside China.
Outside mainland China, overseas Chinese communities may hold commemorative events and discussions about the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
In mainland China, there are no official public commemorations marking the anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
International human rights organizations have called on China to acknowledge and account for the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
The Chinese government does not officially characterize the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown as a massacre.
Wikipedia is among the foreign websites that are restricted from mainland China by the Great Firewall.
Families of some victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown have faced official pressure and harassment aimed at discouraging public commemoration or advocacy.
WeChat content related to politically sensitive topics can be subject to monitoring and deletion in mainland China.
Patriotic education campaigns in China present the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests as a threat to national stability.
The Chinese government’s approved framing argues that the use of force in 1989 was necessary to restore order and maintain stability.
Around the 30th anniversary in 2019, Chinese authorities arrested activists who attempted to commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Access in mainland China to foreign media outlets such as the BBC, CNN, and The New York Times is blocked or heavily restricted.
Hong Kong held large public June 4 candlelight vigils commemorating the Tiananmen victims for many years.
Chinese state messaging has at times portrayed the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests as influenced by hostile foreign forces.
The Chinese government has responded to some foreign criticism of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown by describing it as an internal matter.
Mainland Chinese security forces use checkpoints and heightened security around Tiananmen Square to deter or prevent unauthorized gatherings.
In mainland China, speaking publicly about the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown can lead to professional repercussions, including job loss or demotion.
Archives and collections documenting the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown exist online outside mainland China.
Accessing Tiananmen-related archives from within mainland China can be difficult due to internet censorship.

questions.question: What were the reported arrests and sentencing outcomes for participants after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown?

facts.fact: Reports stated that many of those arrested after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown were workers who had participated in the protests.
Some estimates of the number of people arrested after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown range from about 1,000 to more than 10,000.
Reports stated that many people arrested after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown were sentenced to prison terms.
Some reports stated that some people were sentenced to death after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Reports stated that some people sentenced after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown were charged with "counter-revolutionary activities."
The Chinese government has not disclosed a full accounting of how many people were arrested after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Some reports stated that many people were sentenced to re-education through labor or other forms of administrative detention after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
In the years after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown, Chinese authorities reportedly released some detainees from custody.
Some participants in the 1989 protests were sentenced on charges described by authorities as "inciting unrest."
Chen Ziming was reported to have been sentenced to 13 years in prison in connection with the Tiananmen Square protests.
Some people arrested after the crackdown were held in prisons.
Official reports stated that 1,044 people were put on trial after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Reports stated that some participants were sentenced to death after the crackdown.
Reports stated that some defendants were charged with public-order offenses such as "disturbing public order" after the crackdown.
Student protest leader Wang Dan was sentenced to four years in prison and was released in 1993.
Reports stated that many post-crackdown trials were conducted in secret.
Reports stated that many accused participants were denied access to lawyers in post-crackdown proceedings.
Reports stated that some prisoners were released on medical parole.
After the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown, the Chinese government carried out a nationwide campaign to arrest and prosecute protest participants.
The Chinese government reported that post-crackdown prison or labor camp sentences ranged from a few months to life imprisonment.
Some reported prison sentences for participants extended up to life imprisonment.
Some executed individuals were accused of "counter-revolutionary" activities.
Some prominent activists were able to escape China and go into exile after the crackdown.
Wei Jingsheng was later exiled to the United States.
Chinese authorities conducted trials of some people arrested after the crackdown during the 1989–1991 period.
In post-crackdown trials, some defendants were charged with offenses described as "hooliganism."
According to the answer, many cases involving participants after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown remain unresolved.
Reports stated that human rights groups questioned the fairness of some trials that resulted in death sentences after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Reports stated that the most severe sentences after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown were typically reserved for people deemed to be 'ringleaders' or 'counter-revolutionaries'.
Reports stated that student leader Liu Gang was sentenced to 6 years in prison for "counter-revolutionary propaganda and incitement" after the crackdown.
Reports stated that many people involved in the 1989 protests continued to face persecution and surveillance by Chinese authorities in later decades.
The Chinese government said in a 1990 report that most of those arrested were released after a short period of detention.
Human rights groups and Western governments estimated that between 200 and 400 people were sentenced to life imprisonment or death in connection with the crackdown.
Other estimates put the number of post-crackdown executions at anywhere from a few dozen to over 100.
"Re-education through labor" (RTL) in China at the time involved detention and forced labor.
RTL sentences were often given to people involved in the protests who were not deemed to have committed serious crimes.
Some estimates said tens of thousands of people were sentenced to RTL in connection with the crackdown.
Some RTL detainees were reportedly held for up to four years.
Some exiles reportedly escaped with help from foreign governments or human rights organizations.
Some details about the crackdown remain classified or disputed.
Reports indicated that 'counter-revolutionary' charges in China could carry penalties up to and including the death penalty.
The Tiananmen Square crackdown occurred in Beijing, China, on June 4, 1989.
Human Rights Watch reported that by 2001, an estimated 200 to 300 people were still imprisoned in connection with the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
Some reports described the post-crackdown arrests as numbering in the thousands over the weeks and months after June 1989.
The same 1990 United States Department of State report stated that the prison terms ranged from a few months to life imprisonment.
The 're-education through labor' system described in the answer allowed individuals to be held for up to four years without trial.
Some releases after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown were reportedly influenced by international pressure.

questions.question: What is the "June Fourth" (1989 Tiananmen Square) censorship system in China, including blocked terms and online suppression?

facts.fact: In China, the Chinese government censors online information and discussion related to the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests (the "June Fourth" incident).
Chinese online platforms use keyword filtering to block or restrict sensitive terms related to the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
Chinese internet censorship has included blocking or filtering the keyword "June 4" in contexts related to the 1989 protests.
Chinese online platforms can suspend or terminate accounts for posting content about the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
Images of the "Tank Man" associated with the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests are censored on Chinese internet platforms.
The term "Tiananmen Square" is censored in China when used in the context of the 1989 protests.
"June Fourth" ("6/4") refers to the Chinese government’s June 4, 1989 military crackdown on the 1989 Tiananmen Square protest movement in Beijing.
Chinese social media platforms can monitor content for June Fourth–related sensitive material and remove posts or comments that mention it.
Public commemorations in mainland China related to the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown are generally prohibited or closely policed.
China uses nationwide internet filtering commonly known as the “Great Firewall” to restrict access to online material, including material related to the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
Mainland China’s state-controlled media generally do not report on the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown due to censorship.
Some Chinese internet users use coded language or indirect imagery to discuss or commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests while trying to evade censorship.
The term "6/4" (or "64") is commonly treated as a sensitive reference to June 4, 1989 and is often filtered on Chinese online services.
People in China have been detained or arrested for attempting to commemorate or publicize the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen events.
Chinese authorities conduct online monitoring and surveillance to detect politically sensitive discussion, including discussion of Tiananmen and June 4, 1989.
Some people in China use VPNs or other circumvention tools to attempt to access information blocked by Chinese internet censorship controls.
References to Hu Yaobang can be censored in China in contexts related to the 1989 protests.
China enforces real-name registration requirements for many online services, which can facilitate identifying users who post sensitive content.
Chinese internet platforms employ human content moderators to remove or restrict content deemed politically sensitive, including Tiananmen-related content.
Chinese platforms use automated systems to detect and remove sensitive images related to June Fourth (for example, imagery associated with the 1989 protests).
China’s national internet filtering system can block access to services by blocking IP addresses associated with targeted websites.
Keyword filtering in China is applied to online search queries and user-generated content on platforms such as social media.
WeChat has censored or restricted dissemination of Tiananmen Square–related content on its platform.
China uses automated systems, including machine-learning-based tools, to detect and filter politically sensitive online content in real time.
Chinese authorities commonly increase surveillance and restrict or detain some activists and dissidents around the June 4 anniversary.
Mainland Chinese education materials generally omit or discourage discussion of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
The Chinese government restricts access to foreign news sites that might report on the June 4 anniversary or discuss the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Censorship of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests in China uses both online controls and offline controls.
Image recognition has been used to detect and suppress images of the "tank man" associated with the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
Chinese authorities restrict or block many VPN services used to circumvent internet censorship.
Some people attempt to avoid keyword filters by using code words, homophones, or metaphors to discuss June Fourth-related topics.
The primary purpose of “June Fourth” censorship is to suppress information and discussion about the events of June 4, 1989.
Chinese state media promote an official government narrative about the June 4, 1989 events.
The Chinese education and publishing systems can omit or restrict discussion of the June 4, 1989 events in textbooks and educational materials.
Censorship of Tiananmen Square–related information in China is an ongoing policy rather than a one-time action.
China has employed paid or organized online commentators (often referred to as the "50 Cent Party") to post pro-government messaging online.
People in China have been detained or interrogated by police for online speech deemed politically sensitive, including speech related to the June 4 events.
People in China have faced criminal prosecution for politically sensitive online expression under charges such as "inciting subversion of state power."
Images or references to the "Goddess of Democracy" statue (created during the 1989 protests) are commonly censored on Chinese internet platforms.
Chinese authorities and platforms may temporarily expand keyword blocks related to June 4 around the anniversary period.
Chinese internet censorship is implemented through a combination of online and offline control measures by state authorities.

Offline suppression related to June 4 includes harassment, detention, or house arrest of individuals who were involved in the 1989 protests or who speak publicly about them, especially around the anniversary.
Around June 4, Chinese state media may instead broadcast patriotic programming emphasizing stability and prosperity.
In 2013, internet users used a "big yellow duck" meme as an indirect reference to the "Tank Man" image to evade censorship.
China has specialized police units (often described as "internet police") that monitor online activity and enforce internet regulations.
China has cybersecurity and related laws that provide a legal framework used for online censorship and surveillance.
Chinese internet companies engage in self-censorship to reduce the risk of government penalties.
Journalists in China who attempt to report on the Tiananmen Square events may face censorship or persecution.
The Chinese term "massacre" (屠杀) is often treated as sensitive in the context of discussion of the June 4, 1989 crackdown.
Chinese officials have, in some cases, pressured foreign companies or organizations to avoid public references to the 1989 Tiananmen Square events.
Using circumvention tools or posting censored June 4, 1989 content in China can carry risks of punishment.
Chinese troops and security forces suppressed the 1989 protests.
The 1989 Tiananmen Square movement is widely described as student-led and pro-democracy.
Estimates of deaths from the June 4, 1989 crackdown range from hundreds to thousands.
Chinese authorities monitor participation in June Fourth memorial activities and may detain or interrogate participants.
